Award.AwardTitle: Supporting Transfers to Reach Educational Aspirations in Math and Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Supporting Transfers in Reaching Educational Aspirations in Math and Science (STREAMS) Program at Fresno Pacific University (FPU) will target increasing the number of community college transfer students who obtain science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) baccalaureate degrees and will build on an existing partnership between the university and the College of the Sequoias (COS). STREAMS will identify a diverse population of academically talented community college students with financial need and recruit these students to transfer to math, biology, chemistry, or environmental science program at the university. This project will enhance STEM collaborations between a community college and a four-year institution and increase the number of STEM graduates from populations traditionally underrepresented in STEM including first-generation, Hispanic, and low-income students through recruitment efforts that focus on these groups. In so doing it will increase the number of STEM role models for the younger members of these groups and advance research and practice regarding effective STEM scholarship programs and student support services for transfer students from underrepresented groups. The project will enable the university to continue to develop, apply, evaluate, and advance theories and practices that increase STEM baccalaureate degree attainment among community college transfer students such as articulated transfer agreements, cohort building activities, mentoring, transition-to-university programming, upper-division STEM tutoring, study groups, and graduation guarantees.

The university will augment student support structures to ensure that at least 85% of the scholars obtain a baccalaureate degree within two years of transferring to the university. The project will enhance a number of existing student support services as well as services initiated through a collaboration on a Title V Hispanic Serving Institutions grant program targeting STEM students. These enhancements will include the formation of cohorts, two-year Graduation Guarantees for scholars, a special seminar designed for scholars, robust faculty-student mentoring, upper division STEM tutoring, STEM retention strategies, and Supplemental Instruction. It will enable at least 80% of S-STEM scholars to secure employment or enter a graduate program in a STEM field within one year of graduation. STREAMS will better prepare STEM students for the workforce or graduate programs by providing key support services and activities, including one-on-one STEM career counseling, GRE preparation, job shadowing at local STEM businesses, internship and research opportunities, field trips to STEM businesses and graduate schools, and workshops with STEM industry experts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fresno Pacific University (FPU) implemented the Supporting Transfers in Reaching Educational Aspirations in Math and Science (STREAMS) Project in collaboration with and College of the Sequoias (COS) and built a STEM pathway from a two-year community college to FPU. STREAMS implemented evidence-based best practices to promote STEM transfer student success, especially among student populations traditionally underrepresented in STEM.

 

The evidence-based cohort building, and mentoring activities included a one-credit seminar and a weekend retreat. FPU retained only 20% of the STREAMS scholars who took lightly their participation of the one-credit seminar and the weekend retreat but retained over 80% of the fully participated scholars.

 

The intellectual merit of STREAMS: FPU is able to develop, apply, evaluate, and advance theories and practices that increase STEM transfer student success among underrepresented groups, such as structured STEM pathways between institutions, cohort building, mentoring, transition-to-university programming, upper-division tutoring and study groups, and graduation guarantees.

 

The broader impact of STREAMS: FPU is able to increase the number of STEM graduates from populations traditionally underrepresented in STEM (e.g., socioeconomically disadvantaged students, first-generation college students, and Hispanic students), which will increase the number of STEM role models for the younger members of these groups; and advance research and practice regarding effective STEM scholarship programs and student support services for underrepresented groups.

 

Out of the total 35 STREAMS scholars, 20 are Hispanic or other ethnic minorities (57%). The STREAMS grant has helped underrepresented minorities to complete their degrees successfully. Over half of FPU?s STEM transfers are Pell Grant recipients of which 61% are Hispanic.

 

The STREAMS Project shows that transfers who were academically talented on paper based on their community college GPA may still not be able to graduate successfully, especially for those transferred in without the gateway courses (57% graduation rate) versus those with 2-Year Graduation Guarantee (87% graduation rate). The target rate set for 2-Year graduation was 85%.

 

Out of the 20 STREAMS scholars who graduated as of Spring 2021, 14 are women (70%), 11 are Hispanic or other ethnic minorities (55%). However, 8 out of the 14 who left the program are non-White (57%). Out of the 20 STREAMS graduates, 4 Summa Cum Laude, 5 Magna Cum Laude, and 2 Cum Laude.

 

Four (2 men and 2 women) of the eight FPU students in the 2017 Putnam Competition sponsored by the Mathematical Association of America were STREAMS graduates, whose career goals are being high school Math teachers. Student participants said, “It was an exciting experience to think that we were joining with students all over the nation to complete this difficult set of problems. It was rewarding to be able to apply what we have learned during class, and it is very encouraging to see multiple students wanting to participate and engage with the challenging material that exists in the math world,” and "The challenge of the exam was unparalleled, and it forced me to exercise not only my critical thinking skills, but also my highest level of creativity. As such, I found the exam to be an exciting experience that motivates me to continue to grow in academic excellence alongside my peers. I think it is essential to provide this sort of opportunity to students at Fresno Pacific and to put them on the same playing field alongside the largest, most prestigious universities in the nation.”

 

One of the 2021 graduating STREAMS scholar won the FPU Outstanding Graduate Award, and she will do summer research with Dr. Dean Lee's group at Nationwide Children's Hospital in Ohio. Outstanding graduates are recognized for their academic achievement, moral and ethical character, leadership potential, and service to others. Outstanding graduates are for life the embodiment of the Fresno Pacific Idea and are committed to the ideals of Christian higher education, cultural diversity, peacemaking, justice, and reconciliation. Dr. Dean Lee is himself an FPU Outstanding Graduate giving research and professional development opportunities to our younger STEM students.
